instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.CHGR_ACIN: What is CHGR_ACIN? CHGR_ACIN is a signal that is created by a voltage divider between the charger and ground that goes into the ISL6258, ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip that creates PPBUS_G3H. It is necessary for SMC_BC_ACOK & CHGR_ACOK to be present so that the onewire circuit is told to turn on & allow the SMC to speak to the charger..
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.R7121: What is R7121? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7151: What is R7151? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.Q7180: What is Q7180? Inrush limiter transistor that must be told by the ISL6259 that it is safe to allow charger voltage to pass through to the computer. This needs CHGR_AGATE and CHGR_SGATE to be pulled down in order for it to close and allow voltage through to the system, current sensing failures as well as ISL6259 failures can cause this to happen. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

What about diode mode on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?
Check resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
Also post more pins voltage; 1, 2, 9, 12, 13, 14, 15, 17, 19, 20, 27.

threads.message:
"pin 9: 4 Volt"
Are you sure about this?
In such case, there is a problem with <RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR>/22, or their traces.

"pin 1: 18.16 Volt
................
pin 27: 19.98 Volt"
Seems that <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> is bad.

"Check resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>"
Why don't reply correctly?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not power
threads.message:
Pin 9 : 4 volt sure

I uninstalled the <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> but still the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> gets hot. Then I put a new one, nothing changed.

17/18 : 3.7 ohm
27/28 : 21.5 ohm

pin 27: 19.98 Volt"

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not power
threads.message:
DCIN voltage can't pass through <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> (to <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR> and pin 27/<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>), if pin 1/<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is high; must be low, to drive <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> correctly.

AMON (pin 9/<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>) shows overcurrent through <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR>.
Did you check resistance exactly between <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> pins 17/18?
You may have a broken trace; not good to check just over <CAPACITOR>C7120</CAPACITOR> in this case.
Be sure to have good solders.
If all good, then <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is bad too (apart of <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR>).

You should change <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> too; maybe even <TRANSISTOR>Q7135</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not power
threads.message: I removed f7140/41. I disassembled the <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>/35. I changed the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> 4 times. But again the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is getting hot. It draws 0.08 amps. Currently there is no f7140/41 <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>/35 on the motherboard but it keeps getting hot

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not power
threads.message:
Remove <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and check resistance between pads 17/18 and 27/28.
Also check between pads 19/20.

Be sure all surrounding resistors are good.
Then resolder <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>/35.
Keep F7140/1 out and check again <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> voltages.

Don't forget to change <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not power
threads.message:
Removing good components will not help you.
Put all back; just be sure to be good.
Check any trace and solder.
Then post again <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> voltages, above mentioned.
Change all capacitors surrounding <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, if not sure about them.
Also change <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, if still overheats.

Just keep out F7140/1.

threads.message:
Did you resolder all?

Check/change all components related with pins 21-28.
